questions.question_text:
An administrator wants to leverage the processor-specific technology that uses a security extension for securing virtual machines (VMs). This will allow user-level code to define private regions of memory called enclaves that are protected from external access.
What does the administrator need to configure to enable VMs to use this technology?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Intel SGX allows user-level code to define private regions of memory, called enclaves. The enclave contents are protected such that code running outside the enclave cannot access the enclave contents.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-C81950B5-CD0A-40CA-9945-1104A92F4455.html

Selected Answer: B
Intel SGX allows user-level code to define private regions of memory, called enclaves. The enclave contents are protected such that code running outside the enclave cannot access the enclave contents.

Selected Answer: B
B
Also, The answer seems to be in the first line of the question screenshot .

Selected Answer: B
B is Correct

Selected Answer: B
Definitely B.
The certificate here is not trusted by the browser.
The certificate has not expired yet, so D is incorrect

Selected Answer: B
I had this issue a week ago.
An expired self-signed certificate doesn't let you continue to the VC interface.
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/76719

Other sites say D is correct, but the truth is its a common error for a self signed Cert, no where in the warning does it say the Cert is expired. Its possible to operate With a Self Signed Cert. I guess its how the question is worded. "Best Solution" might be to replace Cert with New. another Gotcha question with no clear answer.

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B, no where in the question does it say the certificate is expired.

comments.content: The article and the answer don't match....the article simply shows a way to (in the author's words)"how you can remove self signed certificate warning". D however says to install a NEW, UNEXPIRED cert; if you can't prove the cert is expired (which you can't from the pic), D can't be correct. Its B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2108294

Selected Answer: B
i think B, there is not evidence why is certificate untrusted, mostly its common problem with own untrusted
 CA

Selected Answer: B
https://masteringvmware.com/how-to-remove-vcenter-certificate-warning/
trick: "to address this" error message ;)
Do you think is B or D ?

Selected Answer: D
d is correct

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An administrator repeatedly encounters this error message while attempting to connect to vCenter Server.
What should the administrator do to address this error message?

choices.B: Trust the VMware certificate authority (CA) root certificate.

questions.question_text: Which two configuration tasks must be performed from the vCenter Server Management Interface? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Add a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server.

discussion.content: B & D is correct

comments.content:
I agree, it appears that B&D are correct.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vcenter.configuration.doc/GUID-B259B969-3E5D-4576-8256-D3BED54B89AF.html
The question includes,"Must Be performed". SSH can also be enabled by logging in to VM's virtual console. So Answer should be B & C

Licensing is not manageable from vCenter Server Management Interface
B and D are correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B & D is correct, it's just the wording of the question. It would have been better if it read something like "What actions can be done from vCenter Server Management Interface"....

Selected Answer: BD
Option "C" is not part of the Management Interface, but B and D are:

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vcenter.configuration.doc/GUID-B259B969-3E5D-4576-8256-D3BED54B89AF.html

Selected Answer: BD
vCenter Server Management Interface is with the port :5480 not 443

B and D.
Those that said "E" was an option. It's not b/c you can do that in the vSphere client by going to vCenter > config > general settings > logging setting

comments.content:
I think it's B and C as well, because you can enable SSH in three different ways accroding to:
https://www.nakivo.com/blog/most-useful-esxcli-esxi-shell-commands-vmware-environment/
@GasserAyad. That article is about ESXi. The question is about vCenter.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
The question includes,"Must Be performed". SSH can also be enabled by logging in to VM's virtual console. So Answer should be B & C
B& D are correct

Selected Answer: BD
it's B and D for sure

comments.content: Hello, how I can find all questions and answers to get prepared? Thank you.

discussion.content: B and D are correct. Passed with 500 today

Selected Answer: BD
Clearly B and D. I was unsure about E, but for sure is not C

Selected Answer: BD
Because it is B & D

B is not correct. You can do so by accessing the appliance shell and log in as an admin or super admin (root). The only option that must be done from the vSMI is D Enable SSH Login. All other options can be done either from the vSphere client or the appliance shell.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vcenter.configuration.doc/GUID-B259B969-3E5D-4576-8256-D3BED54B89AF.html

Selected Answer: BD
B&D IS CORRECT

only those two options are available in VAMI
B and D for sure just access the VAMi and see for yourself

Selected Answer: BD
B & D is correct
Add license is done at Vcenter GUI. so B and D

comments.content:
Ans --> B & D
NTP Configuration --> under Time
Enable/Disable SSH --> under Access

discussion.content: B and D correct
B & D is the correct answer. Login to VAMI via root then configure the B and D.
B and D are correct
B & D is correct

should be B and D, 
Licenses can be managed from vSphere Client > Administration > Licenses

discussion.content:
B&D
regarding C, you can also enable SSH from DCUI (Direct Console User Interface)

comments.content: B & D is correct. the Q asks for actions in VAMI not in vSphere Client (vCenter)

discussion.content: C is incorrect. Licenses can be managed from vSphere Client > Administration > Licenses

Selected Answer: B
"You can use the Instant Clone technology to create powered on virtual machines from the running state of another powered on virtual machine. The result of an Instant Clone operation is a new virtual machine that is identical to the source virtual machine. With Instant Clone you can create new virtual machines from a controlled point in time. **Instant cloning is very convenient for large scale application deployments** because it ensures memory efficiency and allows for creating numerous virtual machines on a single host."

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-853B1E2B-76CE-4240-A654-3806912820EB.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIMYQPYDsCmBnEBfIA

comments.content: vSphere Auto Deploy is for ESXi hosts, not VMs

discussion.content: Can somebody verify this answer? "Rapidly" makes me suspect B's Instant clones, but "hundreds of VMs" sounds like C's Auto Deploy.

questions.question_text:
A development team has a recurring need to rapidly replicate hundreds of virtual machines (VMs) for load testing.
Which method should the team use to deploy the VMs?

choices.C: Full clones using vSphere Auto Deploy
choices.A: Linked clones from a content library
choices.B: Instant clones using the vSphere API

discussion.content: C pass with 500 5-13-23

Selected Answer: C
There must be direct HA network connection between primary and secondary nodes, files and db replication is done via this network. Picture shows no such connection. Replication is not done via witness node. Checked against official course material.

Selected Answer: C
Obviously C

C
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.avail.doc/GUID-2D395533-4C7C-45A6-9B5C-0A78C3E3A5C8.html

Selected Answer: C
Definitely C - in a vCenter HA all three nodes communicate through the HA interfaces, so active and passive are linked as well.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.avail.doc/GUID-2D395533-4C7C-45A6-9B5C-0A78C3E3A5C8.html

Management interface stays only on the active node, so the passive node gets it only when/if it becomes active ;)

comments.content: You are wrong with your answer. There must be direct HA network connection between primary and secondary nodes, files and db replication is done via this network. Picture shows no such connection. Replication is not done via witness node. Checked against official course material.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The management interface on the passive node! C is not correct, traffic between vcenters is through the HA network

choices.D: The management interface and connection on the witness node
choices.B: The management interface on the passive node
choices.C: The connection between the active and passive nodes
